report_title: Ambulatory Surgery Centers in the US
executive_summary: Ambulatory surgery centers (ASCs) offer improved patient quality and care while cutting healthcare costs. Hospitals contend with scheduling delays, limited operating room capacity and budgetary issues for which ASCs provide a cost-effective alternative. Moreover, the advancement of medical technology has made many surgical techniques less invasive, enabling the performance of many inpatient procedures in outpatient settings. The industry's landscape has changed considerably as the medical sector has taken stock of ASCs' success. Once owned predominately by independent physicians, today, ASCs are a highly sought-after acquisition target by medical competitors like hospitals.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: ASCs Have Flourished as a Cost-Efficient Option
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: ASCs have inundated the healthcare sector since the 1970s because they are a high-quality, yet cost-effective alternative to inpatient care administered by hospitals. Since hospitals face scheduling delays, slow operating room turnover times and budgetary issues that limit the ability to purchase new medical equipment, many patients opted for ASCs to receive care. With limited operating room availability in hospitals, further exacerbated by hospital consolidation, ASCs are appealing to many patients. ASCs now perform a range of surgeries, including ophthalmology, orthopedics, gastroenterology and pain management and can more efficiently schedule procedures than hospitals.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: COVID-19 ACCELERATES TRENDS IN ACQUISITION ACTIVITY
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: About 61.0% of ASCs are physician-only owned, followed by hospital-physician (16.0%), corporate-physician (11.0%) and corporate-only (7.0%). However, ASC ownership has shifted away from physician ownership. Hospitals have an ownership interest in about 21.0% of all ASCs, and 3.0% of ASCs are owned solely by hospitals. Hospitals have pursued either sole- or joint-ownership models with ASCs, enabled by the advent of new medical technologies that has reduced the number of procedures that are considered medically invasive.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: GOVERNMENT PAYERS DETERMINE THE REIMBURSEMENT MODEL
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: ASCs contend with regulation at both the federal and state levels. To receive reimbursements from providing care to Medicare beneficiaries, ASCs must report data on quality measures to the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid (CMS). Medicare reimbursements for industry services has significantly expanded to include more procedures, which has also permitted ASCs to bill Medicare separately for ancillary services. Further exacerbating the industry's exposure to regulations, many ASCs have also voluntarily complied with independent accrediting organization's requirements to appeal to patients on the basis of upholding the highest standards of care.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: ASCs Flourish as a Cost-Efficient Option
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: ASCs will likely continue to provide low-cost care in a healthcare system that acutely focuses on containing rising costs. To demonstrate that they provide high-quality care, many ASCs are expected to continue voluntarily joining regulatory compliance entities, such as the ASC Quality Collaboration. The ASC Quality Collaboration sets quality measures, with some endorsed by the National Quality Forum (NQF). ASC will likely continue to provide low-cost services, which will be vital for Medicaid and Medicare to cut costs. According to the Ambulatory Surgery Center Association's (ASCA) analysis of Medicare procedure volumes, ASC procedures for Medicare beneficiaries will save billion every year moving forward.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Aging Demographics Will Push Healthcare Spending Upward
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The aging population drives demand for ASCs because demographic requires more healthcare services compared with other age groups. The number of US residents aged 65 and older is projected to grow more quickly than the total population moving forward. As the population ages, the number of patients suffering from strokes or chronic diseases may increase, raising demand for industry services. Older patients already account for more than one-third of surgical procedures, and Medicare will continue to shift patients from hospital-based surgeries to the ambulatory surgery setting.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Healthcare Companies Build Market Power to Preserve Margins
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Many hospitals will likely form joint partnerships with ASCs, which will allow hospitals to share limited resources. Hospitals will also access superior information technology systems and meet growing patient volumes with ASCs despite the more stringent reimbursement rules they are subject to. Large healthcare companies will be at the forefront of consolidation. UnitedHealth Group, the world's largest healthcare company by revenue, acquired 89 ASC with the purchase of Surgical Care Affiliates in 2022. In response, joint partnerships with hospitals will likely enable ASCs to provide more outpatient services despite the limited number of physicians available.

industry_definition: Ambulatory Surgery Centers (ASCs) are specialized healthcare facilities where surgical procedures are performed on an outpatient basis, meaning patients undergo surgery and go home the same day without an overnight hospital stay. ASCs provide various surgical services, including minor procedures, diagnostic tests and more complex surgeries.

opportunities: Federal funding for Medicare and Medicaid
threats: Number of people with private health insurance

key_trends: Expanding procedure offerings is the lynchpin to success. Increasing capacity allows ASCs to draw in more consumers and diversify offerings, which are subject to reimbursement cuts from payers.
Cost cutting is a hallmark of the ASC substitute. ASCs have effectively limited overhead, siphoning away customers from competitor settings, especially hospitals.
Ambulatory surgery centers (ASCs) are cost competitive. ASCs have grown at the expense of hospitals because more procedures can be performed in ambulatory settings at lower cost.
Both private insurance and government payers like Medicare have incentivized ASCs to contain cost growth.
Changing regulations, tech advances and payer support bring value to ASCs that attract consolidation and private equity interest.
Government payers foot the bill for nearly one-quarter of all industry bills.
Profitability has increased as government payers have pushed outpatient procedures.
The Southeast has the largest population, warranting a greater need for ASCs to meet the region's medical needs.
Private payers have incentivized patients to use ambulatory surgery centers instead of

market_segmentation.segment_description: Private health insurance includes commercial insurance (PPO, HMO) and private health plans purchased directly or through a marketplace.

Government insurers include Medicare and Medicaid. Medicare provides insurance to people aged 65 and older or with disabilities; Medicaid administers benefits to qualifying individuals (low-income households, pregnant women and people with disabilities).
Out-of-pocket payments include payments by patients for medical care not covered by insurance. This includes deductibles, copayments and coinsurance.

Examples of other revenue sources include reimbursements from various federal, state and local programs; workers' compensation; auto and property insurers; maternal and child health programs; the Department of Defense; the Department of Veterans Affairs; charitable contributions; grants and miscellaneous private sources.

products_and_services.product_or_service: Musculoskeletal System and Connective Tissue Diseases
products_and_services.product_description: The musculoskeletal system and connective tissue segment includes patients who are treated for rheumatoid arthritis, joint disorders, osteoporosis and other muscle, joint, tendon, neck, foot and back-related disorders.

products_and_services.product_or_service: Nervous System and Sense Organ Diseases
products_and_services.product_description: Nervous system and sense organ diseases include vascular disorders, infections (e.g. meningitis), structural disorders (e.g. peripheral neuropathy) and other disorders (e.g. Parkinson's disease).
Respiratory system diseases include chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), atelectasis, or a collapsed lung, among several other ailments.

Digestive system diseases include celiac disease, inflammatory bowel disease and irritable bowel syndrome. Typically, patients with digestive system diseases receive lower gastrointestinal (GI) endoscopies.
Symptoms, signs and ill-defined conditions includes patients that have either two or more diseases or have symptoms related to ailments that have affected two or more symptoms of the body.
The injury and poisoning category includes fractures and other injuries, such as ACL injuries. It also includes allergies, animal bites sprains, and burns.

tier_1_buyers: Health & Medical Insurance in the US

demand_determinants.determinant_description: Ambulatory surgery centers depend on reimbursements from private insurers for care delivered to in-network patients. Changes in the number of people with private insurance influence access to healthcare services and the amount received in reimbursements.

business_locations.location_description: The Southeast region is home to the largest number of ambulatory surgery centers (ASCs) because of the region's extensive population. Florida leads all states in the region, outperforming other states as a primary location choice because of its high concentration of older individuals.

The West is the industry's second most concentrated region, accounting for nearly a quarter of all ASCs. California has more ASCs than any other state. As the most populous state in the United States, California has millions of residents seeking healthcare services. A high population density creates a demand for healthcare facilities, including ASCs, to meet the population's needs.

The Mid-Atlantic's share of ASCs mirrors its share of the population. Maryland, New York, Pennsylvania and New Jersey have some of the highest concentrations of ASCs in the country. Densely populated cities in New York influence the number of ASCs in the state. New York City has more residents than North Dakota, Wyoming and Alabama combined, warranting a greater need for more hospitals. The Mid-Atlantic region has a well-developed healthcare infrastructure, including hospitals, physician practices and outpatient facilities. An established infrastructure supports the opening and operation of ASCs, which are integrated into the broader healthcare system to provide outpatient care.

regulations_points.regulation_description: Ambulatory Surgery Centers (ASC) are required to obtain licensing from regulatory agencies in most states to ensure that they meet quality and procedural standards. Many states also require ambulatory surgery centers to receive accreditation from third-party groups. "Certificate of need" (CON) laws in some states require new companies to show need for services and new facility construction.

regulations_points.regulation_title: THE CENTERS FOR MEDICARE AND MEDICAID SERVICES
regulations_points.regulation_description: Certification from the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services (CMS) is required for ASCs that seek reimbursement from Medicare. Medicare's certification requirements, also known as Conditions of Coverage, cover various operating aspects, from facility design to procedural processes. Most importantly, CMS determines payment rates that Medicaid and Medicare pay service providers.

regulations_points.regulation_title: THE HEALTH INSURANCE PORTABILITY AND ACCOUNTABILITY ACT
regulations_points.regulation_description: The Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act (HIPAA) works to protect both the confidentiality of people receiving medical treatment and providers. The law necessitates that the Department of Health and Human Services set standards for electronic transactions and national identifiers for healthcare providers, plans and employers. The law also covers data security and privacy by setting procedural standards.

The Health Information Technology for Economic and Clinical Health (HITECH) mandates audits of healthcare providers to ensure compliance with HIPAA. The HITECH Act strengthens HIPAA by incentivizing providers to adopt electronic health records (EHRs) and enforcing steeper penalties for noncompliance.

regulations_points.regulation_title: ANTI-KICKBACK STATUTE AND PHYSICIAN SELF-REFERRAL LAWS
regulations_points.regulation_description: The federal Anti-Kickback Statute prohibits the exchange of anything of value (financial incentives, low rents, excessive compensation) for the referral of any business reimbursable by federal healthcare programs (Medicare, Medicaid). Kickbacks promote overutilization of healthcare, create higher costs and corrupt decision-making by steering patients away from valid services. Physical self-referral law prohibits physicians from referring patients to a healthcare service if they or a family member have a financial relationship with that entity.

barriers_points.barrier_description: Ambulatory surgery centers (ASCs) must obtain licensing and meet accreditation requirements at the state level. ASCs must also obtain accreditation at the federal level to receive reimbursement from Medicare. Becoming Medicare-certified and accredited and state-licensed requires a considerable time investment.
ASCs require large up-front costs in facilities construction, equipment and technology purchases. An estimated $500,000 to $1.5 million in equity cash is

basis_points.basis_description: ASCs perform a wide array of procedures, and diverse service offerings provide a safety net to changing reimbursement rates.

Labor costs make up the largest expense for ASCs because of the skilled nature of procedures. Despite technological advancements, competition for labor has stiffened because ASCs compete with hospitals and other medical settings for workers.

concentration_points.concentration_title: SCALE REMAINS LIMITED IN THE INDUSTRY
concentration_points.concentration_description: The Ambulatory Surgery Centers industry is characterized by a high degree of fragmentation. Many ambulatory surgery centers (ASCs) cater to local and regional markets.

Large ASC networks have more negotiating power with larger government payers, allowing them to maintain high margins even as reimbursement rates shrink. New partnerships with acute-care and nursing facilities also allow ASCs to treat patients for longer periods of time.

cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Purchases include the cost of dispensing drugs and medical supplies to patients. While medical supplies, including pharmaceuticals and surgical equipment, have increased in cost, ASCs pass these costs onto medical payers.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Mounting Expenses Offset Rising Patient Volumes' Impact on Profit
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Ambulatory surgery centers (ASCs) vary widely in size and ownership structure, creating huge profit gaps between the smallest and the largest. Still, rising patient volumes at ASCs over the past two decades have averaged profit hovering above 20.0%.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Hiring Challenges Pressure ASCs to Raise Wages
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Wages have historically been the single-largest expense for ambulatory surgery centers. Managing labor costs has become more complex as ASCs confront staffing shortages and rising patient volumes.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Labor costs make up the largest expense for ASCs because of the skilled nature of procedures. Despite technological advancements, competition for labor has stiffened because ASCs compete with hospitals and other medical settings for workers.

volatility_points.volatility_description: The indispensable nature of medical procedures limits revenue volatility, as demand for surgeries is not subject to economic fluctuations. As the number of adults aged 65 and older has risen, more ASCs have obtained Medicare certification to capitalize on stable revenue source.

volatility_points.volatility_title: ASCS ARE VIEWED AS COST-EFFECTIVE ALTERNATE
volatility_points.volatility_description: ASCs are viewed as a cost-effective, high-quality option relative to hospitals. As a result, many healthcare insurers have funneled rising patient volumes to ASCs to curb rising healthcare costs.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: NEW TECHNOLOGIES DRIVE GROWTH OF AMBULATORY SURGERY CENTERS (ASCS)
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Technological advancements have expanded the role of ASCs in the healthcare system. ASCs are performing increasingly complex procedures like orthopedic and spine surgeries.

The ASC setting is, like the broader healthcare system, leveraging automation to do more with less. Automated systems are being used for automated phone calls and reminders to patients, decreasing administrative volumes to increase volumes and reduce costs.

FAQs.question: How does your company market its services to the wider community, including rural areas?
FAQs.answer: Ambulatory surgery centers provide quick, convenient care to communities at a lower cost than emergency room visits. In addition, in rural areas, centers provide care where patients have poor access to primary care.

FAQs.question: Has increased access to health insurance offered opportunities for your company?
FAQs.answer: Privately insured individuals represent a significant portion of total revenue for ASCs, so expanding health insurance coverage has benefited operators. Overall, demand for healthcare services rises with increased access to health insurance.

FAQs.question: Has your company considered expanding into metropolitan areas?
FAQs.answer: Large cities are often home to chains or groups, as they benefit from a more extensive client base and can stay operational 24/7.

FAQs.question: How can you encourage visits from individuals who lack health insurance?
FAQs.answer: Some centers offer installment payment plans and discounted rates for people paying out of pocket.

FAQs.question: Has your company explored offering telehealth services to improve patient accessibility and improve efficiency?
FAQs.answer: Some care centers offer telehealth services to see patients more efficiently and reduce costs.

FAQs.question: Is your company investing in new technology to improve existing surgical techniques?
FAQs.answer: Investing in the latest, best surgical technology allows a center to perform a wide array of procedures that are less invasive.

FAQs.question: Is your company adequately prepared to adjust to intensifying regulations?
FAQs.answer: Uncertainty surrounding federal healthcare reform is a major concern for many physicians.

FAQs.question: Have any new mandates, as a result of healthcare reform, expanded your client base?
FAQs.answer: Healthcare reform that expands access to health insurance would benefit the industry.

FAQs.question: How does your company's profit compare with the industry average?
FAQs.answer: Financial performance is linked to the ability to compete on price and access capital to fund expansion and growth.

FAQs.question: How does your company account for the seasonality of cash flow?
FAQs.answer: Many facilities see an uptick in foot traffic during the summer season, when individuals are more active and accident prone. Advertising your facility in off-season months can help adjust for the seasonality of cash flow.

FAQs.question: Do you have a good reputation for excellent customer service? How do you hire the best-skilled workers?
FAQs.answer: After attracting individuals through direct-to-consumer marketing, providing quality care increases the incentive for customers to return to a center and recommend their services to others.

FAQs.question: How have you been affected by government policies?
FAQs.answer: Federal requirements continue to be developed with respect to the industry, and legislation, particularly with regard to reimbursement and admission rates for specific product offerings, can prove detrimental to operators focused on these segments.

FAQs.question: How do you attract and retain qualified staff? What qualifications must your staff have? Do you have a high turnover rate?
FAQs.answer: Talented and specialized doctors are required for each of the industry's product offerings, and largely determine the amount of consumer demand for an ambulatory surgery center.
